resources.string: Ideally, this app needs location permissions in order to accurately calculate the zmanim. Therefore, it is better to allow the app to see your location. We do not use your location for any other purpose than to calculate the zmanim.\n\nHowever, if you still do not want to give location permissions, you can choose to search for your address or a zipcode and the app will find your location based on your approximate area. (Using a zip code is not recommended if you want accurate Zemanim. It is better to put in your address.)
If you want to use Mishor (Sea Level) Sunrise/Sunset for your calculations of the zemanim, just press the button below:
If you want to specify the elevation level (in meters) yourself, press this button:
If you want to get this information from GeoNames.com, press this button:

Rabbi Asher Darshan (who was on the team for the Ohr HaChaim calendar in Israel) told me that Rabbi Ovadia Yosef ZT\"L held that the actual sunrise/sunset that should be used for calculating zmanim is when sunrise/sunset is seen at the highest point in the city. However, Rabbi David Yosef Shlita writes that many have told him that Rabbi Ovadiah ZT\"L held to use Mishor (Sea Level) sunrise/sunset. Rabbi Leeor Dahan says that it makes sense to use elevation in cities that have hills, and to not use it when the city, E.G. New York, is close to sea level. You can use the buttons below to choose the appropriate settings that you want. (See Halacha Berura vol. 14, in Otzrot Yosef (Kuntrus Ki Ba Hashemesh), Siman 6, Perek 21 for an in depth discussion)

Welcome to the Rabbi Ovadia Yosef Calendar app (also known as Zemaneh Yosef), this app was made to help you find out the most accurate Zemanim of the day according to Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef ZT"L for your own city! Please follow the "Get Started" process of the app to set it up and here are some things to keep in mind:


1.) You should ideally choose your city and download the visible sunrise tables through the simple setup. This table contains the most accurate times for VISIBLE sunrise, and this is the algorithm that the Ohr HaChaim calendar uses in Israel as the Yalkut Yosef writes (Yalkut Yosef Tefila 1, page 48). However, these tables only go on for 2 years into the future and will need to be updated bi-yearly. If you do not want to use these tables, you can choose to skip the setup, and the app will instead use the regular NOAA algorithm for sunrise (without elevation included as it is similar enough).


2.) There are a few different minhagim to choose from in the settings part of the app. Make sure to choose the correct ones for your city/kehila. For example, the default candle lighting time is set to 20 minutes before sunset, and the default end time for shabbat is set to 40 minutes after sunset. Please change these settings to your own customs if desired.


3.) Lastly, the zmanim can be included with seconds, DO NOT RELY ON THESE SECONDS. The only zman that can be relied on to the second is the visible sunrise time based on chaitables.com. Otherwise, these zmanim are NOT accurate to the second! You should always round up or down a minute or two just in case.


In addition to all of this, there are features in place that will automatically tell you to update the elevation data or the visible sunrise tables. If you leave the city that you currently setup the app for, the app will prompt you to run the setup again. The reason for this feature is because elevation will change based on the city that you are located in and you will have to update it every time you change cities, however, this feature will only turn on if you use elevation. If you have any issues or concerns, send an email to: ElyahuJacobi@gmail.com
Setup both elevation and visible sunrise (advanced)
Do Not setup anything\n\n(Uses Mishor/Sea Level Sunrise and Sunset for both zmanim and Sunrise)
Press this button to download the visible sunrise table from the Chai Tables website:

This "Visual Sunrise" setup will replace our listed sunrise times with their equivalent from the ChaiTables.com website & "Bechorei Yosef" calendar in Israel. These times are more accurate for those who pray Shaḥarit by sunrise, and they're in use by the Ohr HaChaim calendar in Israel.

All you need to provide is your country and metro area (with it sometimes asking for a state too). Our table-downloader will first find the smallest radius of your town, and then download the tables for the next two years. For future years, the table will reuse information saved from this setup to load your data as seamlessly as possible.

If you want to specify more information (such as a custom radius size), you should instead use our "Advanced Setup" - this will allow you to specify your own ChaiTables link to scrape from. You could navigate the website in our app if you don't have a ChaiTables link.

It will then ask you if you want to setup elevation for the city the app is set to. Know that the elevation data changes for each and every city and you will need to set the elevation data of your city every time you change cities.
What language would you like the zemanim to be in?
Disclaimer: Times are just for reference, you should ask a rav if you can say the bracha earlier or later.
The Molad for This Month (Your Timezone)
Press the button below to download the visible sunrise times for your area. You can choose the advanced setup if you want to specify a link or more options.
If you want to specify what to setup:
Please select a method to find your location
Please go to chaitables.com and create a table of the current year for the area you specified. Then copy the link/address of the table and enter it here:
Go to the website in the app
This widget will show the current days most important zmanim
If you are in Israel now, please confirm below.
No, I am not in Israel
If you are not in Israel now, please confirm below. Otherwise, ignore this message.
No, I have not left Israel
Would you like to receive real-time notifications for zemanim?

If you would like to receive real-time zemanim notifications for your current location, please navigate to the settings page and enable location services all the time for this app. Do not forget to check your battery saver settings as well. Would you like to do this now?
The visible sunrise tables for the current location and year need to be updated.\n\nDo you want to update the tables now?

WARNING! Entering a zipcode will give you zemanim based on approximately where you are, and they will not be as accurate. For more accurate zmanim, please allow the app to see your location or enter an EXACT address.
Press back again to close the app
How to get info from chaitables.com

(I recommend that you visit the website first.) 

Choose your area and on the next page all you need to do is to fill out steps 1 and 2, and click the button to calculate the tables on the bottom of the page.

Make sure your search radius is big enough and leave the jewish year alone. The app will do the rest.
Please enter a valid value, for example: 11024
The whole 15th night of the hebrew month
Do NOT rely on the seconds!

DO NOT RELY ON THESE SECONDS. The only zman that can be relied on to the second is the visible sunrise time based on chaitables.com. Otherwise, these zemanim are NOT accurate to the second! You should always round up or down a minute or two just in case.
No email app, please contact elyahujacobi@gmail.com
Please Enter a valid value, for example: 30 or 30.0
Something went wrong. Is the link correct?
Something went wrong connecting to the website.
Something went wrong. Did you choose the right area?
Something went wrong connecting to the website. Please try again later.
Display the seconds of the zemanim
Display sea level sunrise even if visible sunrise is setup as well
Display the dialogs when you press on a zeman
Display if it is Shabbat Mevarchim on Saturday
Display when Shabbat or Chag ends the day before
Show Shabbat End Times the day before?
Display Rabbenu Tam or regular shabbat end times or both
Set the elevation to the last known location when the app is opened offline
Set elevation to last known location?
Choose a theme for the app
Choose the color of the background
Choose your own image as the app\'s background
Choose the color of the text
Choose the color of the calendar button
Choose whether or not to use a dark calendar icon for the calendar button
Click here to see the help page
Display the current elevation level in the daily view
Display the time for elevated sunrise that is used for calculating the zmanim
Display if it is a leap year
Show if it is a leap year?
Display if Daylight Savings is in effect
Choose which opinion to use for the time for when shabbat/chag ends
Enter the amount of minutes to add to sunset for shabbat to end
Enter the amount of minutes for candle lighting
Choose which opinions to use for the time of the tekufot
Extend/Shorten the times of twilight based on their degree equivalent, while still using seasonal minutes (Only outside Israel)
Minutes before the zeman for notifications
Notifications on Shabbat and Yom Tov?
View rabbinic approbations for this application
Choose which haskama you would like to view below.
Purim prayers will show on the 14th (yesterday)

In Tanach this time is called Alot HaShachar (בראשית לב:כה), whereas in the gemara it is called Amud HaShachar.

This is the time when the day begins according to halacha. Most mitzvot (commandments), Arvit for example, that take place at night are not allowed to be done after this time.
After this time, mitzvot that must be done in the daytime are allowed to be done B'dieved (after the fact) or B'shaat hadachak (in a time of need). However, one should ideally wait until sunrise to do them L'chatchila (optimally).

This time is calculated as 72 zmaniyot/seasonal minutes (according to the GR"A) before sunrise. Both sunrise and sunset have elevation included.

In Luach Amudei Horaah mode, this time is calculated by finding out how many minutes are between sunrise and 72 minutes as degrees (16.04) before sunrise on a equal day with sunrise and sunset set around 12 hours apart. Then we take those minutes and make them zmaniyot according to the GR"A and we subtract that time from sunrise to get the time for Alot Hashachar. This is according to the Halacha Berurah and this should only be done outside of Israel in more northern or southern areas.

Misheyakir (literally "when you recognize") is the time when a person can distinguish between blue and white. The gemara (ברכות ט) explains that when a person can distinguish between the blue (techelet) and white strings of their tzitzit, that is the earliest time a person can put on their talit and tefilin for shacharit.

This is also the earliest time one can say Shema L'chatchila (optimally).

This time is calculated as 6 zmaniyot/seasonal minutes (according to the GR"A) after Alot HaShachar (Dawn).

Note: This time is only for people who need to go to work or leave early in the morning to travel, however, normally a person should put on his talit/tefilin 60 regular minutes (and in the winter 50 regular minutes) before sunrise.

In Luach Amudei Horaah mode, this time is calculated by finding out how many minutes are between sunrise and 72 minutes as degrees (16.04) before sunrise on a equal day with sunrise and sunset set around 12 hours apart. Then we take those minutes and make them zmaniyot according to the GR"A and we subtract 5/6 of that time from sunrise to get the time for Misheyakir. This is according to the Halacha Berurah and this should only be done outside of Israel in more northern or southern areas. The Halacha Berurah writes to do this because it is more according to the nature of the world, however, it does not seem like Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef ZT"L or the Yalkut Yosef agrees with this opinion. Elevation is not included in Luach Amudei Horaah mode.

This is the earliest time when all mitzvot (commandments) that are to be done during the daytime are allowed to be performed L\'chatchila (optimally). Halachic sunrise is defined as the moment when the top edge of the sun appears on the horizon while rising. This halachic sunrise is called mishor (sea level) sunrise and it is what many jews rely on when praying for Netz.\n\nHowever, it should be noted that the Shulchan Aruch writes in Orach Chayim 89:1, \"The mitzvah of shacharit starts at Netz, like it says in the pasuk/verse, \'יראוך עם שמש\'\". Based on this, the poskim write that a person should wait until the sun is VISIBLE to say shacharit. In Israel, the Ohr HaChaim calendar uses a table of sunrise times from the luach/calendar \'לוח ביכורי יוסף\' (Luach Bechoray Yosef) each year. These times were made by Chaim Keller, creator of the ChaiTables website. Ideally, you should download these VISIBLE sunrise times from his website with the capability of this app by pressing the button below. However, if you did not download the times, you will see \'Mishor\' or \'Sea Level\' sunrise instead.

This is the latest time a person can eat Chametz before Pesach begins.

This is calculated as 4 zmaniyot/seasonal hours, according to the Magen Avraham, after Alot HaShachar (Dawn) (elevation affects this time). Since Chametz is a mitzvah from the torah, we are stringent and we use the Magen Avraham's time to calculate the last time a person can eat chametz since it results in an earlier time.

Outside of Israel, this time is calculated the same way as above except using the adjusted Alot/Tzet from the Amudeh Horaah calendar that is based on the distance from the equator.

If Erev Pesach falls out on Shabbat, this zman represents the latest time a person can have the day meal with chametz.

This is the latest time a person can own Chametz before Pesach begins. You should get rid of all Chametz in your possession by this time.

This is calculated as 5 zmaniyot/seasonal hours, according to the MG"A, after Alot HaShachar (Dawn) (elevation affects this time).

Outside of Israel, this time is calculated the same way as above except using the adjusted Alot/Tzet from the Amudeh Horaah calendar that is based on the distance from the equator.

If Erev Pesach falls out on Shabbat, even though you can not burn chametz, this time represents the latest time a person can own Chametz on Shabbat. You would still need to get rid of it/destroy it before this time.

This is the latest time a person can fulfill his obligation to say Shma everyday according to the Magen Avraham.

The Magen Avraham/Terumat HeDeshen calculate this time as 3 zmaniyot/seasonal hours after Alot HaShachar (Dawn). They calculate a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between Alot HaShachar (Dawn) and Tzeit Hachocavim (Nightfall) of Rabbeinu Tam and divide it into 12 equal parts.

In Luach Amudei Horaah mode, this time is calculated the same way as above except using the skewed Alot/Tzait of the Amudei Horaah calendar, and no elevation is included.

This is the latest time a person can fulfill his obligation to say Shma everyday according to the GR"A (HaGaon Rabbeinu Eliyahu)

The GR"A calculates this time as 3 zmaniyot/seasonal hours after sunrise (elevation affects this time). The GR"A calculates a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between sunrise and sunset (elevation affects this time) and divides it into 12 equal parts.

In Luach Amudei Horaah mode, this time is calculated the same way as above except no elevation is included.

This is the latest time a person can say the Brachot Shma according to the GR\"A. However, a person can still say Pisukei D\'Zimra and Amidah until Chatzot.\n\nThe GR\"A calculates this time as 4 zmaniyot/seasonal hours (based on sunrise to sunset) after sunrise (elevation affects this time).

This is the middle of the halachic day, when the sun is exactly in the middle of the sky relative to the length of the day. It should be noted, that the sun can only be directly above every person, such that they don't even have shadows, in the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn. Everywhere else, the sun will be at an angle even in the middle of the day.

After this time, you can no longer say the Amidah prayer of Shacharit, and you should preferably say Musaf before this time.

This time is calculated as 6 zmaniyot/seasonal hours after sunrise. The GR"A calculates a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between sunrise and sunset and divides it into 12 equal parts.

Mincha Gedolah, literally "Greater Mincha", is the earliest time a person can say Mincha. It is also the preferred time a person should say Mincha according to some poskim.

It is called Mincha Gedolah because there is a lot of time left until sunset.

A person should ideally start saying Korbanot AFTER this time.

This time is calculated as 30 regular minutes after Chatzot (Mid-day). However, if the zmaniyot/seasonal minutes are longer, we use those minutes instead to be stringent. The GR"A calculates a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between sunrise and sunset (elevation affects this time) and divides it into 12 equal parts. Then we divide one of those 12 parts into 60 to get a zmaniyot/seasonal minute.

Mincha Ketana, literally "Lesser Mincha", is the most preferred time a person can say Mincha according to some poskim (Rambam, Shulchan Aruch).

It is called Mincha Ketana because there is less time left until sunset.

This time is calculated as 9 and a half zmaniyot/seasonal hours after sunrise. The GR"A calculates a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between sunrise and sunset (elevation affects this time) and divides it into 12 equal parts. Then we divide one of those 12 parts into 60 to get a zmaniyot/seasonal minute.

Plag HaMincha, literally "Half of Mincha", is the midpoint between Mincha Ketana and sunset. Since Mincha Ketana is 2 and a half hours before sunset, Plag is half of that at an hour and 15 minutes before sunset.

You can start saying arvit/maariv by this time according to Rabbi Yehudah in (ברכות כ'ו ע'א).

A person should not accept shabbat before this time as well.

The Halacha Berurah says to calculate this time by subtracting an hour and 15 zmaniyot minutes from sunset, however, the Yalkut Yosef says to calculate it as 1 hour and 15 zmaniyot/seasonal minutes before tzeit (13.5 zmaniyot minutes). 

Outside of Israel, tzet hakokhavim is deviated to accommodate the change in location.

The GR"A calculates a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between sunrise and sunset (elevation affects this time) and divides it into 12 equal parts. Then we divide one of those 12 parts into 60 to get a zmaniyot/seasonal minute.

This is the ideal time for a person to light the candles before shabbat/chag starts. However, bediavad, a person can light the candles as late as five minutes before sunset if they were not able to light it at the appropriate time.

If it is Shabbat going into a Yom Tov that has candle lighting, the candles are lit after Tzeit/Nightfall. However, if the next day is Shabbat, the candles are lit at their usual time before sunset.

You have this time set to be calculated as %s regular minutes before sunset (elevation affects this time).

The Ohr HaChaim calendar always shows the candle lighting times for 20 and 40 minutes before sunset.

This is the time of the day that the day starts to transition into the next day according to halacha.

Halachic sunset is defined as the moment when the top edge of the sun disappears on the horizon while setting (elevation affects this time).

Immediately after the sun sets, Bein Hashmashot/twilight starts according to the Geonim, however, according to Rabbenu Tam the sun continues to set for another 58.5 minutes and only after that Bein Hashmashot starts for another 13.5 minutes.

It should be noted that even though Rabbi Ovadia says that you can say mincha until nightfall, many poskim, like the Mishna Berura, say that a person should ideally say mincha BEFORE sunset and not before Tzeit/Nightfall.

Most mitzvot that are to be done during the day should ideally be done before this time.

Tzeit/Nightfall is the time when the next halachic day starts after Bein Hashmashot/twilight finishes.

This is the latest time a person can say Mincha according Rav Ovadiah Yosef Z"TL. A person could start the amidah of mincha at any time that is at least before this time. (Yabia Omer 7 Siman 34)

This time is shown in gray on shabbat and yom tov (as advised by our rabbeim) in order to not let people think that shabbat/yom tov ends at this time.

This time is calculated as 13 and a half zmaniyot/seasonal minutes after sunset (elevation affects this time).

The GR"A calculates a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between sunrise and sunset (elevation affects this time) and divides it into 12 equal parts. Then we divide one of those 12 parts into 60 to get a zmaniyot/seasonal minute.

Outside of Israel, this time is calculated by finding out the amount of minutes between sunset and when the sun is 3.7 degrees below the horizon on the equinox (12 hours between sunrise and sunset), then we add that amount of zmaniyot minutes to sunset all year round to get the time of Tzeit/Nightfall. We use 3.7 degrees below the horizon because that is the time when it is 13.5 minutes after sunset in Israel.

This time is calculated as 20 seasonal minutes after sunset (elevation affects this time) (Yalkut Yosef Siman 261:2).

This time is important for fast days and deciding when to do a brit milah. Otherwise, it should not be used for anything else like the latest time for mincha.

This time is shown in gray on shabbat and yom tov (as advised by our rabbeim) in order to not let people think that shabbat/yom tov ends at this time.

Outside of Israel, this time is calculated by finding out the amount of minutes between sunset and 5.075 degrees below the horizon on the equinox (12 hours between sunrise and sunset), then we add that amount of zmaniyot minutes to sunset all year round to get the time of Tzeit/Nightfall L'Chumra. We use 5.075 degrees below the horizon because that is the time when it is 20 minutes after sunset in Israel.

This time is calculated as 20 seasonal minutes (outside of Israel, 20 seasonal minutes adjusted based on the distance from the equator) after sunset (elevation affects this time) (Yalkut Yosef Siman 261:2).

It is brought down in Halacha Berurah (vol. 14, in Otzrot Yosef [Kuntrus Ki Ba Hashemesh]) that Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef Z"TL was once traveling in New York on Tisha Beav and he said to his son, Rabbi David Yosef Shlita, that the fast ends at tzeit geonim (13.5 zmaniyot minutes after sunset). However, in his sefer Chazon Ovadiah (Arba Taaniyot Page 12), he writes that the fast ends around 20 minutes after sunset.

In the Ohr HaChaim calendar, they write that the fast ends at Tzait Hacochavim. Rabbi Benizri (author of the calendar) explains that it refers to either 13.5 or 20 minutes after sunset, and he said, "The calendar just says that the fast ends at Tzait Hacochavim, a person can end the fast at 20 minutes after sunset if he wants to be stringent."

We have set the end time of the fast to be at the 20 minute time because the Chazon Ovadia quoted above is stringent for fasts, however, someone who wants to end the fast at the 13.5 minute time has the right to do so.

This is a more stringent time that the fast/taanit ends. This time is according to the opinion of Chacham Ben Zion Abba Shaul.\n\nThis time is calculated as 30 regular minutes after sunset (elevation affects this time).

This is the time that Shabbat/Chag ends.

Note that there are many customs on when shabbat ends, by default, it is set to 30 regular minutes after sunset (elevation affects this time) in Israel. Rabbi Meir Gavriel Elbaz Shlita has told me that anywhere outside of Israel, if you wait 40 regular minutes after sunset, that is for sure enough time to end shabbat.

Outside of Israel, this time is calculated by using a degree of 7.165. We use this degree because Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef ZT"L ruled that regarding Motzeh Shabbat the listed time should be set as 30 fixed minutes after sunset. This degree is interpreted as 30 minutes after sunset all year round in Israel. You can change this time in the settings to accommodate your communities minhag.

This time is Tzeit/Nightfall according to Rabbenu Tam.

Tzeit/Nightfall is the time when the next halachic day starts after Bein Hashmashot/twilight finishes.

According to Rabbeinu Tam, these 72 minutes are made up of 2 parts. The first part is 58 and a half minutes until the second sunset (see Pesachim 94a and Tosafot there). After the second sunset, there are an additional 13.5 minutes until Tzeit/Nightfall.

Rabbi Ovadia writes (Halichot Olam, Chelek 1, Page 250, Halacha 2 and Yalkut Yosef Siman 261:1) that it is proper to wait until the time of Rabbenu Tam has passed for biblical matters like Shabbat and Yom Kippur. Rabbi David Yosef (Halacha Berura Siman 293) includes Yom Tov into this stringency. However, it should be noted that second day Yamim Tovim are not biblical and therefore do not need this stringency.

This time is calculated as 72 zmaniyot/seasonal minutes after sunset (elevation affects this time). However, outside of Israel, this time is calculated by finding out the amount of minutes between sunset and when the sun is 16.04 degrees below the horizon on the equinox (when there is 12 hours between sunrise and sunset) and adding that amount of zmaniyot minutes to sunset all year round. In more northern places in the world, this adjustment will make the time for Rabbenu Tam extremely late, therefore, we limit the maximum time limit for Rabbenu Tam to 72 regular minutes. This is based on Yalkut Yosef Siman 293:6 and Halacha Berurah 15 Page 42.

The GR"A calculates a zmaniyot/seasonal hour by taking the time between sunrise and sunset (elevation affects this time) and divides it into 12 equal parts. Then we divide one of those 12 parts into 60 to get a zmaniyot/seasonal minute in order to calculate 72 minutes.

This is the middle of the halachic night, when the sun is exactly in the middle of it's solar transit of the celestial meridian after it sets. It should be noted, that the sun can only be directly underneath in the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn. Everywhere else, the sun will be at an angle even in the middle of the night.

It is ideal to have Melaveh Malka before this time.

This time is calculated as 6 zmaniyot/seasonal hours (based on sunset of today and sunrise of the next day) after sunset.

When Rosh Chodesh happens during a leap year, we add the words, \"וּלְכַפָּרַת פֶּשַׁע\" during Musaf. We only add these words from Tishri until the second month of Adar. However, for the rest of the year and during non leap years we do not say it. (Chazon Ovadiah Chanukah 306)

This number represents the amount of elevation that you are applying to your zmanim to see sunrise/sunset in your current city in meters. If the number is set to 0, then you are calculating the zmanim by mishor/sea level sunrise and sunset.\n\nThere is a debate as to what Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef Z\"TL held about using elevation for zmanim. (See Halacha Berura vol. 14, in Otzrot Yosef (Kuntrus Ki Ba Hashemesh), Siman 6, Perek 21 for an in depth discussion) The Ohr HaChaim calendar uses elevation for their zmanim, however, Rabbi David Yosef Shlita holds that the elevation is not used for zmanim. Rabbi Leeor Dahan Shlita has told me that it makes sense to use elevation in areas that are located on top of mountains. However, in areas that are by the sea, for example New York, you would not use elevation.

This is the time that the tekufa (season) changes.

There are 4 tekufas every year: Tishri (autumn), Tevet (winter), Nissan (spring), and Tammuz (summer). Each Tekufa happens 91.3125 (365.25 / 4) days after the previous Tekufa.

The Achronim write that a person should not drink water when the seasons change. Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef Z"TL writes (in Halichot Olam, Chelek 7, Page 183, Halacha 8) that a person should not drink water from a half hour before this time till a half hour after this time unless there is a slim piece of iron in the water.

NOTE: This only applies to water, not to other drinks.

Both the Ohr HaChaim and the Amudei Horaah calendars use the above method to get the time for the tekufa. However, the Amudei Horaah calendar differs from the Ohr HaChaim calendar, by using the local midday time of Israel. Which causes a 21 minute difference. Therefore, the Amudei Horaah calendar time for the tekufa will always be 21 minutes before the Ohr HaChaim's time.

In practice, it is recommended to keep both times if possible as it is only adding an additional 21 minutes.

Here is a list of days with no tachanun:

Every Rosh Chodesh
Every Shabbat
Every Yom Tov
Chol HaMoed
Isru Chag (day after chag)
The entire month of Nissan
Pesach Sheni (14th of Iyar)
Lag Ba'Omer
Rosh Chodesh Sivan until the 12th of Sivan (7 days after Shavuot and the 12th is included)
9th of Av
15th of Av
Erev Rosh Hashanah and Rosh Hashanah
Erev Yom Kippur and Yom Kippur
From the 11th of Tishri (day after Yom Kippur) until the end of Tishri
Every day of Chanukah
15th of Shevat
14th and 15th of Adar I and Adar II
Purim Meshulash for walled cities (safek included)
Tu Be'Shvat

In all of these cases tachanun is not said as well as for mincha the day before them. The exclusion to this rule is Erev Rosh Hashana and Erev Yom Kippur which are already before their respective days.

For Yom Yerushalayim and Yom Ha'atzmaut, since there is a debate, we simply wrote that some say tachanun. According to Rabbi Meir Gavriel Elbaz, the minhag of Rabbi Ovadiah ZT"L (as they did in the Yechave Da'at Yeshiva/Kollel) was to only skip tachanun on the day of Yom Yerushalayim. Not the day before it or on Yom Ha'atzmaut. However, Rabbi Yonatan Nacson writes that you are allowed to skip tachanun on both days.

Note that there are other times you should not say tachanun, but this list is only for calendar days with no tachanun. There are multiple other cases where you can skip tachanun. For example: if there are mourners making up majority of the minyan, if there is a simcha (joyous occasion like a Brit Milah, Bar Mitzva, or Siyum Masechet), if tzet hacochavim/nightfall already passed, and many more cases.

During the time of the Three weeks/Nine days/Shevuah shechal bo certain restrictions apply:

Three Weeks:
No listening to music
Better to delay shehechiyanu

Nine Days:
No listening to music
Better to delay shehechiyanu
Better to delay any construction
No weddings
No purchasing new clothing (unless there is great need ex: a sale)
No consumption of meat or wine (excludes Rosh Chodesh and Shabbat)
No wearing brand new clothing

Shevuah Shechal Bo:
No listening to music
Better to delay shehechiyanu
No construction
No weddings
No purchasing new clothing (unless there is great need ex: a sale)
No consumption of meat or wine
No wearing brand new clothing
No taking haircuts or shaving (Men Only)
No swimming (with hot water)
No showering (with hot water)
No laundry
No wearing freshly laundered clothing (excludes undergarments)

Birchat HaChamah is said today! This occurs once every 28 years, and a person should be careful to say the beracha on the sun early in the morning on this day.

According to many poskim, you can say the beracha on the sun all day, however, Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef ZT"L writes in Chazon Ovadiah Berachot that a person should try to say the beracha before 3 zmaniyot hours into the day. If this time passes, he should say the beracha without hashem's name.

It should be noted that it is the minhag of Am Yisrael to wake up early and pray at Netz on this day and after the Amidah (Kadish Titkabal), they go outside to say the beracha.
When did you start your meal?
Did you start your meal before sunset?

When praying the Amidah, one should direct himself towards Israel, Jerusalem, the temple mount and the Kodesh Hakodashim (Holy of Holies) area (Berakhot Bavli 30a, based on Kings I 8:35–48 & Chronicles II 6:32). Determining which direction that is in can be done through the \"Rhumb line\" method, which \"draws\" a line from one\'s location to a specific point (which in our case, would be the Temple mount). Once the line is drawn, you are expected to pray in the direction the line is drawn in through matching your direction with its degree angle. Please note that even if the Aron in the synagogue that you are in is misplaced, you should not separate from the others. Rather, you should only adjust your head to the right direction.
The application will NOT track your location
The application will keep requesting your location

Birchat Halevana, also known as Kiddush Levana and "The blessing for the new moon", is a beracha we say once a month on the moon a few days after it reaches it's new waning phase. (שולחן ערוך אורח חיים סימן תכו)

It is ideal to say this blessing with a minyan on Saturday night with a nice suit on. (מעם לועז בראשית א:יד)

The time period for this blessing starts from 3 days after the Molad (new moon), however, Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef ZT"L (and sephardim in general) recommend to wait until 7 days after the molad to make the beracha. This time period ends on the 15th of every hebrew month according to Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef. (הליכות עולם חלק ה אות ט"ז)

During the six-year cycle prior to shemita, there is an obligation to separate and gift portions of your field\'s grains, fruits and vegetables grown in Israel to various causes (Bamidbar 18). We separate Terumah Gedolah, Maaser Rishon, and Terumat Maaser every year, however, Maaser Sheni is replaced with Maaser Ani on the 3rd and 6th years (Devarim 14:28).

Would you like to setup visible sunrise times as well?

This application has the ability to download more accurate sunrise times from 'chaitables.com'. The setup has been based on the website version, however, it has been simplified as well. The Yalkut Yosef (Tefila 1:48) writes that the times for visible sunrise on this website are recommended to be used over any other sunrise time for praying at Netz.

The reason why we need you to go to the website is because the website uses a massive amount of data to calculate the times. It is not something so easily available on a phone.

You can always download the times at a later point in time within the app by opening the Netz dialog (press on the zman to see it) and pressing on 'Setup Visible Sunrise'.
Enable this if you want to always calculate Rabbeinu Tam as a 10th of the day (72 non-deviated zmaniyot minutes)
Always use a 10th of the day for Rabbenu Tam

We are the platform to use whenever and wherever you\'d need Halachic Times (Zemanim) according to Hakham Ovadia Yosef zt\'l, following his practices represented in his Ohr Hachaim calendar from Eretz Yisrael. Outside Israel, our algorithm follow\'s the rules outlined by the Minḥat Kohen (as quoted by R David Yosef, approved by R Yitzḥak Yosef) to comply with the astronomical differences while sticking to seasonal minutes.
Tip: You can press on the times to find out more information on them!

Every night during the Omer we say a blessing for doing a mitzvah and then say the count which leads us from Passover to Shavuot, from the barley harvest to the wheat harvest and, ultimately, to the first offering on Shavuot itself of wheat from the new harvest, in the form of 12 loaves. During the time the Omer was counted, barley from each week would be brought into the Temple and waved as an offering, really as a prayer that the harvest would come in successfully.

Each day between the beginning of Passover and Shavuot gets counted, 49 days in all, 7 weeks of seven days. That makes the Omer period a miniature version of the Shmitah and Yovel (Jubilee) cycle of 7 cycles of seven years.

The Omer count is made starting the evening of each day – when the count happens at night the blessing is said and when the count happens during the daytime the blessing is not said. After the blessing the day is counted by absolute number and by its number within each week, i.e., “Today is the thirty-third day of the Omer, which is four weeks and five days” – that’s Lag Ba’omer (lamed plus gimel, ל + ג = 33).

The biggest challenge of counting the Omer is that there are some poskim (Baha"g) that hold that it is one long mitzvah lasting 49 days, while others (Rambam) hold that each day is a separate mitzvah. Even though the Shulchan Aruch holds that each day is a separate mitzvah, the practice is if you go one whole night and day without counting you no longer say the blessing because of Safek Berachot LeHakel.
Olives, dates, grapes, figs and/or pomegranates

Haskama by Rabbi Eliyahu Ben Chaim

והנכון הוא ללכת אחר לוח אור החיים, או לוח ביכורי יוסף, וכדומה, המבוסס על הזריחה המוקדמת ביותר הנראית מעל אופק המזרחי האמיתי, מנקודה כלשהי בישוב, מידי יום ביומו, בסיוע מודל טופוגרפי ממוחשב של ארץ ישראל.
(ילקוט יוסף מהדורא תשפ״א סימן פ״ט סעיף ג)
